title: Proportions: Chocolate Manufacturing
question_text:
A certain chocolate bar is advertised as having a weight of $1\text{ ounce}$.
To minimize the number of consumer complaints about underweight candy bars, the candy company sets its machines to produce chocolate bars whose weights are normally distributed with $\mu = 1.1\text{ ounces}$ and $\sigma = 0.08\text{ ounces}$.
What proportion of chocolate bars will weigh $1\text{ ounce}$ or more?
solution:
The question asks to find $P(X \ge 1)$.

First use the conversion formula to find the equivalent $z$-value of $1\text{ ounce}$:

$$z = \dfrac{(X-\mu)}{\sigma} $$

$$z = \dfrac{(1-1.1)}{0.08} = -1.25$$

Now use the table of standard normal probabilities or your calculator to find $P(z\ge-1.1) = 1 â€“ 0.1056 = 0.8944$

The table will give you the left area of the graph shown above, and so to answer the question asked, you must subtract this probability from 1.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
